hints.content: First, understand the definition of a 'strong pair'. A pair of integers (x, y) is strong if the absolute difference |x - y| is less than or equal to the minimum of x and y. This means that x and y should be relatively close in value.
Consider the implications of the condition |x - y| <= min(x, y). For example, if x = 5 and y = 3, then |5 - 3| = 2, and min(5, 3) = 3. Since 2 <= 3, (5, 3) is a strong pair.
You can select the same integer twice to form a pair, which means pairs like (x, x) are valid strong pairs. This could simplify your search for maximum XOR values.
To find the maximum XOR, you will need to calculate the XOR for all valid strong pairs. Remember that XOR is commutative, so (x, y) and (y, x) will yield the same result.
Start by iterating through all possible pairs of indices in the array. You can use a nested loop to generate all combinations of i and j where i and j can be the same.
While iterating through pairs, check if they satisfy the strong pair condition. If they do, calculate the XOR and keep track of the maximum XOR value found.
Pay attention to edge cases, such as when the array has only one element. In that case, the only pair you can form is (nums[0], nums[0]).
Remember that the input constraints allow for a maximum of 50 elements, and each element is between 1 and 100. This means your solution can afford to be O(n^2) since n is relatively small.
When calculating the XOR, be mindful of the properties of XOR: x XOR x = 0, which means pairs like (x, x) will not contribute to the maximum XOR unless x is 0.
Finally, after checking all pairs, return the maximum XOR value found. Make sure your function handles the case where no strong pairs yield a positive XOR correctly.

questionNotes: Pairs can include the same integer twice.
Return the maximum XOR value from strong pairs.
